THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“š Theory Card: Present Continuous (I am doing) ğŸ“š

Theory:

ğŸ”¹ The Present Continuous tense is used to describe an action that is in progress at the moment of speaking.

ğŸ”¹ It is formed using the present form of "to be" (am, is, are) + the present participle of the main verb (-ing form).

ğŸ”¹ The Present Continuous tense is often used to talk about actions that are temporary or ongoing.

ğŸ”¹ It can also be used to express an action that is interrupted by another action.

Examples:

ğŸ“ I am studying for my exam right now. (interrupted by another action)

ğŸ“ She is working on her project. (ongoing action)

ğŸ“ They are not doing anything at the moment. (temporary action)

ğŸ“ The company is expanding its business. (ongoing action)

ğŸ“ The children are playing outside. (temporary action)

ğŸ“ The teacher is grading papers. (ongoing action)

ğŸ“ The storm is getting worse. (interrupted by another action)

TOPIC: Present Simple (I do)
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“š Theory Card: Present Simple (I do) ğŸ“š

Theory:

ğŸ”¹ The Present Simple tense is used to describe habits, routines, and general truths.

ğŸ”¹ The Present Simple is formed using the base form of the verb (e.g. do, go, eat) and the subject pronoun (e.g. I, you, he/she/it, we, they).

ğŸ”¹ The Present Simple can be used to talk about things that happen regularly or repeatedly, such as daily routines or general truths.

ğŸ”¹ There are several exceptions to the rule, such as the verb "to be" and its forms (am, is, are).

Examples:

ğŸ‘‰ I do yoga every morning.
ğŸ‘‰ She goes to the gym three times a week.
ğŸ‘‰ They are studying English every day.

ğŸ”¹ The Present Simple can also be used to talk about future plans or arrangements, using the auxiliary verb "will" or "be going to."

ğŸ‘‰ I will do my homework tonight.
ğŸ‘‰ They are going to visit their grandparents next week.

ğŸ”¹ Additionally, the Present Simple can be used to express a request or a command, using the auxiliary verb "let" or "make."

ğŸ‘‰ Let's go to the movies tonight.
ğŸ‘‰ Make sure to finish your homework before dinner.

ğŸ”¹ And, the Present Simple can be used to express a possibility or a hypothetical situation, using the auxiliary verb "would."

ğŸ‘‰ I would study harder if I were you.
ğŸ‘‰ They would be late if they didn't hurry up.

ğŸ”¹ That's it! The Present Simple tense is a versatile and widely used tense in English, and mastering it will help you communicate more effectively in everyday situations. ğŸ“š

TOPIC: Comparison of Present Continuous and Present Simple 1 (Usage differences and contexts)
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“š Theory Card: Comparison of Present Continuous and Present Simple 1 (Usage differences and contexts) ğŸ“š

Theory:

The Present Continuous and Present Simple tenses are often used interchangeably, but they have distinct differences in usage and context. Here are the key differences:

ğŸ”¹ Present Continuous (PC): Used to describe an action that is in progress at the moment of speaking, and has a temporary or changing nature.

ğŸ”¹ Present Simple (PS): Used to describe an action that is happening repeatedly, generally, or as a habit.

Here are some examples to illustrate the differences:

ğŸ”¹ PC:

* I am studying for my exam right now. (temporary action)
* She is working on her project this week. (changing nature)
* They are rehearsing for their play every day. (in progress)

ğŸ”¹ PS:

* I go to the gym three times a week. (habit)
* She likes to read books in her free time. (generally)
* They have a meeting every morning at 9 am. (repeated action)

In summary, the Present Continuous is used for temporary or changing actions, while the Present Simple is used for habitual or general actions.

ğŸ“š Examples:

* I am studying for my exam right now (PC)
* I go to the gym three times a week (PS)
* She is working on her project this week (PC)
* She likes to read books in her free time (PS)
* They are rehearsing for their play every day (PC)
* They have a meeting every morning at 9 am (PS)

TOPIC: Comparison of Present Continuous and Present Simple 2 (Further explanations and examples)
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“š Theory Card: Comparison of Present Continuous and Present Simple 2 ğŸ“š

Theory:

The Present Continuous and Present Simple tenses are both used to describe actions that are happening now, but they have some differences in their usage and meaning.

ğŸ”¹ Present Continuous:

* Used to describe an action that is in progress at the moment of speaking.
* Indicates that the action is temporary or ongoing.
* Used with "be" verbs (am, is, are, be, being, been).

Examples:

ğŸ‘‰ I am studying for my exam right now.
ğŸ‘‰ She is writing a letter to her friend.
ğŸ‘‰ They are having a meeting at 2 PM.

ğŸ”¹ Present Simple:

* Used to describe an action that is true in general, but not necessarily happening at the moment of speaking.
* Indicates that the action is permanent or habitual.
* Used with all verbs, not just "be" verbs.

Examples:

ğŸ‘‰ I study English every day.
ğŸ‘‰ She goes to the gym three times a week.
ğŸ‘‰ They have a meeting every Monday.

ğŸ”¹ Comparison:

* Use the Present Continuous when the action is temporary or ongoing, and the Present Simple when the action is permanent or habitual.
* The Present Continuous is more formal than the Present Simple.

ğŸ“ Examples:

ğŸ‘‰ I am studying for my exam right now (Present Continuous).
ğŸ‘‰ I study English every day (Present Simple).
ğŸ‘‰ They have a meeting every Monday (Present Simple).

ğŸ”” Note:

* The Present Continuous and Present Simple can be used together to emphasize the temporary or ongoing nature of the action.

ğŸ‘‰ I am studying for my exam right now, but I will finish soon. (Present Continuous + Present Simple)

ğŸ‘‰ She is writing a letter to her friend, but she will finish later. (Present Continuous + Present Simple)

ğŸ‘‰ They are having a meeting at 2 PM, but it will last for an hour. (Present Continuous + Present Simple)

TOPIC: Past Simple (I did)
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“š Theory Card: Past Simple (I did) ğŸ“

Theory:

ğŸ”¹ The Past Simple tense is used to describe actions or events that happened in the past and were completed at a specific time.

ğŸ”¹ The Past Simple is formed using the infinitive form of the verb without "to" and the subject pronouns "I" and "we" use "did" instead of "do".

ğŸ”¹ The Past Simple can be used to talk about past habits, past events, past experiences, and past actions that were completed at a specific time.

ğŸ”¹ There are three main aspects of the Past Simple: Simple Past, Past Continuous, and Past Perfect.

Examples:

ğŸ“ I did my homework last night. (Simple Past)

ğŸ“ She was studying when I arrived. (Past Continuous)

ğŸ“ They had finished their project before the deadline. (Past Perfect)

ğŸ”¹ The Past Simple can also be used in clauses with "when", "before", "after", and "while" to talk about past events and actions.

ğŸ“ I went to the store when I saw the sale. (Past Simple in a clause with "when")

ğŸ“ They had not eaten dinner before they went to the party. (Past Simple in a clause with "before")

ğŸ“ I was studying for my exam while my friend was watching TV. (Past Simple in a clause with "while")

I hope this theory card helps you understand the Past Simple tense better! ğŸ˜Š

TOPIC: Past Continuous (I was doing)
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“š Theory Card: Past Continuous (I was doing) ğŸ“š

Theory:

ğŸ”¹ The Past Continuous tense is used to describe an action that was in progress at a specific point in the past.

ğŸ”¹ It is formed using the past simple of the auxiliary verb "be" (was/were) and the present participle of the main verb.

ğŸ”¹ The Past Continuous tense is often used to show that an action was in progress at a specific point in the past, and then interrupted by another action or event.

Examples:

ğŸ“ I was studying for my exam when the doorbell rang. (interrupted by the doorbell)

ğŸ”¹ Note: The Past Continuous tense can also be used to show that an action was in progress at a specific point in the past, but not interrupted by another action or event.

ğŸ“ I was studying for my exam all morning. (no interruption)

ğŸ“ She was cooking dinner all evening. (no interruption)

TOPIC: Introduction to Present Perfect (I have done) - Basic uses and formation
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“š Theory Card: Introduction to Present Perfect (I have done) - Basic Uses and Formation ğŸ“š

Theory:

The Present Perfect tense is used to describe an action that started in the past and continues up to the present moment. It is formed using the present tense of "have" + the past participle of the main verb. The Present Perfect is used to talk about experiences, events, and actions that have happened at an unspecified time in the past, but are still relevant now.

Here are some basic uses and exceptions of the Present Perfect tense:

ğŸ”¹ To talk about experiences and events in the past that are still relevant now:

* I have traveled to many countries. (The action of traveling started in the past and continues up to the present.)
* She has just moved to a new house. (The action of moving started in the past and is still ongoing.)

ğŸ”¹ To talk about actions that started in the past and are still in progress:

* I have been studying English for three years. (The action of studying started in the past and is still ongoing.)
* They have been working on the project for months. (The action of working started in the past and is still ongoing.)

ğŸ”¹ To talk about actions that happened at an unspecified time in the past:

* I have never been to Paris. (The action of going to Paris happened at an unspecified time in the past.)
* She has always been a good student. (The action of being a good student happened at an unspecified time in the past.)

Examples:

ğŸ“ I have done my homework. (The action of doing homework started in the past and is now completed.)
ğŸ“ They have just arrived. (The action of arriving started in the past and is now completed.)
ğŸ“ I have been learning English for two years. (The action of learning English started in the past and is still ongoing.)

Remember, the Present Perfect tense is a versatile tense that can be used in a variety of ways to talk about the past and the present. Practice using it in your everyday conversations and writing to improve your English skills! ğŸ’ª

TOPIC: Advanced Present Perfect (I have done) - Complex sentences and exceptions
THEORY_CARD:
Theory Card: Advanced Present Perfect (I have done) - Complex Sentences and Exceptions ğŸ“š

Theory:
The Advanced Present Perfect tense (I have done) is used to describe an action that started and finished in the past, but the result of the action is still relevant to the present. It is formed using the present perfect form of "have" (have done) and the past participle of the main verb.

Here are some complex sentences and exceptions to keep in mind:

ğŸ”µ Exception 1: When the action started and finished in the past is not specified, we use the present perfect tense.

Example: I have done my homework, but I haven't finished yet.

ğŸ”µ Exception 2: When the action started in the past and continues up to the present, we use the present perfect tense.

Example: I have been studying English for three years, and I still have a lot to learn.

ğŸ”µ Complex Sentence 1: When using the present perfect tense with "since" and "for," we need to use the present perfect form of "have" (have done).

Example: I have been studying English since I was a teenager.

ğŸ”µ Complex Sentence 2: When using the present perfect tense with "ago," we need to use the past participle of the main verb.

Example: I did my homework two hours ago.

Examples:

ğŸ“ I have been waiting for three hours, but the concert still hasn't started.

ğŸ“ She has just finished her homework, and now she can go out and play.

ğŸ“ They have been studying English for a year, and their language skills have improved a lot.

I hope this theory card helps you understand the Advanced Present Perfect tense and its complex sentences and exceptions! ğŸ˜Š

TOPIC: Present Perfect Continuous (I have been doing)
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“š Theory Card: Present Perfect Continuous (I have been doing) ğŸ“š

Theory:

* The Present Perfect Continuous tense is used to describe an action that started in the past and continues up to the present moment.
* It is formed using the present perfect form of "have" (have been) and the present participle of the main verb (doing).
* The Present Perfect Continuous is used to show that an action has been in progress for a period of time and is still ongoing.

Examples:

ğŸ“ I have been studying English for three years. (I started studying English three years ago and I am still studying now.)

ğŸ“ She has been working at the company for ten months. (She started working at the company ten months ago and she is still working there now.)

ğŸ“ They have been living in Tokyo for five years. (They started living in Tokyo five years ago and they are still living there now.)

ğŸ“ The company has been expanding its business globally. (The company started expanding its business globally some time in the past and it is still expanding now.)

ğŸ“ The research has been ongoing for two years. (The research started two years ago and it is still ongoing now.)

TOPIC: Comparing Present Perfect Continuous and Simple (Usage and differences)
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“š Theory Card: Comparing Present Perfect Continuous and Simple (Usage and differences) ğŸ“š

Theory:

ğŸ”¹ The Present Perfect Continuous (PPC) and the Simple Present (SP) are both used to talk about actions that started in the past and continue up to the present moment.

ğŸ”¹ However, there are some key differences between the two tenses:

ğŸ”º PPC emphasizes the duration and completion of an action, while SP emphasizes the fact that an action started and continues up to the present.

ğŸ”º PPC is used to talk about actions that have a specific time frame, while SP is used to talk about actions that started in the past and continue indefinitely.

ğŸ”º PPC is more formal than SP and is often used in formal writing and speaking.

Examples:

ğŸ“ PPC: I have been studying English for three years now, and I can finally hold a conversation in the language. (emphasizes the duration and completion of the action)

ğŸ“ SP: I have been studying English for three years, and I can finally hold a conversation in the language. (emphasizes the fact that the action started and continues indefinitely)

ğŸ“ PPC: She has been working at the company for five months, and she is still learning new things. (emphasizes the duration and completion of the action)

ğŸ“ SP: She has been working at the company for five months, and she is still learning new things. (emphasizes the fact that the action started and continues indefinitely)

ğŸ”¹ In summary, PPC is used to talk about completed actions with a specific time frame, while SP is used to talk about actions that started in the past and continue indefinitely. Both tenses are important and can be used in different contexts to convey different meanings.

TOPIC: Expressing duration with "how long" (Usage in questions and contexts)
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“š Theory Card: Expressing Duration with "How Long" (Usage in Questions and Contexts) ğŸ“š

Theory:

* Use "how long" to ask about the duration of an action or state.
	+ E.g. How long have you been studying English?
	+ E.g. How long will the project take?
* Use "how long" in questions to ask about the duration of an action or state in the past, present, or future.
	+ E.g. How long did you study English yesterday?
	+ E.g. How long will you study English tomorrow?
* Use "for how long" to ask about the duration of an action or state in the past or future.
	+ E.g. For how long have you been studying English?
	+ E.g. For how long will you study English tomorrow?
* Use "how long ago" to ask about the duration of an action or state in the past.
	+ E.g. How long ago did you start studying English?
	+ E.g. How long ago did you finish your project?
* Use "how long will it take" to ask about the duration of an action or state in the future.
	+ E.g. How long will it take to finish your project?
	+ E.g. How long will it take to learn English?

Examples:

ğŸ“ How long have you been studying English? (asking about the duration of an action in the past)
ğŸ“ How long will the project take? (asking about the duration of an action in the future)
ğŸ“ For how long have you been studying English? (asking about the duration of an action in the past)
ğŸ“ For how long will you study English tomorrow? (asking about the duration of an action in the future)
ğŸ“ How long ago did you start studying English? (asking about the duration of an action in the past)
ğŸ“ How long will it take to finish your project? (asking about the duration of an action in the future)

I hope this theory card helps you understand how to use "how long" in questions and contexts! ğŸ˜Š

TOPIC: Using "for" and "since" with Present Perfect (Duration and starting point)
THEORY_CARD:
Theory Card: Using "for" and "since" with Present Perfect (Duration and starting point).

Theory:

* "For" and "since" can be used with the Present Perfect tense to describe durations and starting points.
* "For" is used to describe a duration that started in the past and continues up to the present.
	+ Examples:
		- I have been studying English for three years. (duration started in the past and continues up to the present)
		- She has been working at this company for three months. (duration started in the past and continues up to the present)
* "Since" is used to describe a starting point in the past and a duration that continues up to the present.
	+ Examples:
		- I have been living in London since January. (starting point in the past and duration continues up to the present)
		- They have been married since 2005. (starting point in the past and duration continues up to the present)

Examples:

ğŸ“ I have been studying English since I was a teenager. (starting point in the past and duration continues up to the present)
ğŸ“ She has been working at this company since last year. (starting point in the past and duration continues up to the present)
ğŸ“ They have been living in Paris for three months. (duration started in the past and continues up to the present)
ğŸ“ I have been waiting for two hours. (duration started in the past and continues up to the present)

TOPIC: Comparing Present Perfect and Past Simple 1 (Differences in usage based on time relevance)
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“š Theory Card: Comparing Present Perfect and Past Simple 1 (Differences in usage based on time relevance) ğŸ“š

Theory:

ğŸ”¹ The Present Perfect tense is used to describe an action that started in the past and continues up to the present moment.

ğŸ”¹ The Past Simple tense is used to describe a completed action in the past.

ğŸ”¹ The main difference between the two tenses is their time relevance. The Present Perfect is used when the action is still relevant to the present, while the Past Simple is used when the action is completed and no longer relevant to the present.

Examples:

ğŸ”¹ Present Perfect:

ğŸ‘‰ I have been studying English for three years. (The action started in the past and continues up to the present.)

ğŸ‘‰ She has just finished her homework. (The action started recently and is still ongoing.)

ğŸ‘‰ They have been on vacation for two weeks. (The action started in the past and is still ongoing.)

ğŸ”¹ Past Simple:

ğŸ‘‰ I studied English for three years. (The action is completed and no longer relevant to the present.)

ğŸ‘‰ She finished her homework. (The action is completed and no longer relevant to the present.)

ğŸ‘‰ They went on vacation for two weeks. (The action is completed and no longer relevant to the present.)

Remember, the Present Perfect is used to describe actions that started in the past and continue up to the present, while the Past Simple is used to describe completed actions in the past that are no longer relevant to the present. ğŸ“š

TOPIC: Comparing Present Perfect and Past Simple 2 (More complex comparisons)
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“š Theory Card: Comparing Present Perfect and Past Simple 2 (More complex comparisons) ğŸ“š

Theory:

The Present Perfect and Past Simple tenses are both used to talk about past events, but they have some key differences in their usage and meaning. Here are some more complex comparisons between the two tenses:

ğŸ”¹ Use the Present Perfect when the action started in the past and continues up to the present:

* I have been studying English for three years, and I still have a lot to learn.
* She has just finished her homework, but she needs to review it before submitting it.

ğŸ”¹ Use the Past Simple when the action started and finished in the past:

* I went to the store and bought some milk.
* She finished her project last night.

ğŸ”¹ Use the Present Perfect when the action started in the past and has a connection to the present:

* I have been working on this project for months, and I'm finally making some progress.
* She has been studying for her exam all day, and she's feeling confident.

ğŸ”¹ Use the Past Simple when the action started and finished in the past, and there is no connection to the present:

* I went to the beach last weekend.
* She finished her internship last month.

Examples:

ğŸ“ Present Perfect:

* I have been learning how to play the guitar for a year now, and I can finally play some simple songs.
* She has been studying abroad for six months, and she's gained a lot of new experiences.

ğŸ“ Past Simple:

* I went to the park and played with my dog.
* She finished her homework and watched a movie.

Remember, the Present Perfect is used to talk about actions that started in the past and continue up to the present, while the Past Simple is used to talk about actions that started and finished in the past. ğŸ“š

TOPIC: Differentiating "have" and "have got" (Usage in possession, relationships, and obligations)
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“š Theory Card: Differentiating "have" and "have got" (Usage in possession, relationships, and obligations) ğŸ”

Theory:

ğŸ” Have and have got are both used to express possession or ownership, but they have some key differences in their usage and connotations.

ğŸ” Have is a more general term that implies possession or ownership without any specific implications. It is often used to describe a permanent or long-term relationship with an object or a person.

ğŸ’• Have got, on the other hand, implies a more temporary or specific relationship, often with a sense of possession or control. It is often used to describe a more casual or recent acquisition.

ğŸ¤ Have can also be used to describe a relationship or an obligation, while have got is more commonly used to describe a physical object or a possession.

Examples:

ğŸ“š I have a book. (permanent possession)

ğŸ“ I have got a pen. (temporary possession)

ğŸ‘« I have a friend who speaks French. (relationship)

ğŸ“ I have got a meeting at 2 PM. (obligation)

ğŸ”‘ Note that have got is often used in informal contexts, while have is more formal and widely accepted in all contexts.

ğŸ‘ I hope this helps you differentiate between have and have got in your English language learning journey! ğŸ˜Š

TOPIC: Usage of "used to" (Describing past habits and states no longer true)
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“š Theory Card: Usage of "used to" (Describing past habits and states no longer true)

* "Used to" is used to describe past habits and states that are no longer true.
* It is often used to talk about things that happened regularly in the past, but do not happen anymore.
* "Used to" can also be used to describe past states that were true for a period of time, but are no longer true.

Examples:

ğŸƒâ€â™€ï¸ I used to go to the gym every day, but I don't do that anymore.

ğŸ“š She used to study English every evening, but now she only studies on weekends.

ğŸ½ï¸ They used to eat meat, but now they are vegetarians.

ğŸŒ I used to live in a cold climate, but now I live in a warm place.

ğŸ“š Note: "Used to" can also be used to describe past habits and states that were true for a specific period of time, but are no longer true. For example: "I used to work at that company from 2010 to 2015."

TOPIC: Using Present Tenses for Future (I am doing / I do)
THEORY_CARD:
Theory Card: Using Present Tenses for Future (I am doing / I do).

Theory:

* Present tense can be used to describe future actions or events.
	+ This is known as the "present for the future" or "present prolepsis."
	+ It is commonly used to talk about plans, schedules, or predictions.
* The present tense is used to emphasize the certainty or predictability of the future event.
	+ For example, "I am going to the movies tonight" (the speaker is certain about their plans).
	+ For example, "I do exercise every morning" (the speaker has a regular routine).

Examples:

ğŸ¬ I am seeing a movie tonight at 8 PM.
ğŸ‹ï¸â€â™€ï¸ I do yoga every morning at 6 AM.
ğŸ“ I am meeting my friend for lunch at 12 PM.
ğŸ“š I do my homework every day before bed.

Note: The present tense can also be used to describe hypothetical or uncertain future events, but in this case, it is not as common.

TOPIC: Introduction to "will" and "shall" 1 (Simple future intentions and promises)
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“š Theory Card: Introduction to "will" and "shall" 1 (Simple future intentions and promises) ğŸ“š

Theory:

* "Will" and "shall" are both used to express future intentions and promises, but they have slightly different connotations and uses.
* "Will" is more informal and is used to express a spontaneous decision or a future plan that is not yet finalized.
	+ E.g. "I will go to the store later."
	+ E.g. "I will try to finish the project by tomorrow."
* "Shall" is more formal and is used to express a future action that is already planned or arranged.
	+ E.g. "I shall attend the meeting at 2 PM."
	+ E.g. "I shall finish the report by the end of the week."

Examples:

ğŸ“ "I will go to the beach this weekend." (informal, spontaneous decision)
ğŸ“ "I shall attend the conference next month." (formal, planned action)

TOPIC: Advanced "will" and "shall" 2 (Subtleties and formal uses)
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“š Theory Card: Advanced "will" and "shall" 2 (Subtleties and formal uses) ğŸ“

Theory:

* "Will" and "shall" are both used to express future actions, but they have some subtle differences in their meanings and uses.
	+ "Will" is more commonly used for spontaneous decisions or actions that are not yet planned or arranged.
		- "I will go to the store later."
		- "I will call you back later."
	+ "Shall" is more commonly used for future actions that are planned or arranged in advance.
		- "I shall attend the meeting tomorrow."
		- "I shall finish the report by the end of the week."
	+ "Shall" is also used for making offers or giving promises.
		- "I shall make sure to be there on time."
		- "I shall help you with your project."
	+ "Will" can also be used for making offers or giving promises, but it is less formal and more commonly used in informal contexts.

Examples:

ğŸ“ "I will meet you at the park at 3pm." (spontaneous decision)
ğŸ“ "I shall attend the conference next month." (planned action)
ğŸ“ "I will help you move this weekend." (offer)
ğŸ“ "I shall finish the project by the end of the year." (promise)

Note: The use of "will" and "shall" can vary depending on the context and the speaker's preference. It's important to understand the subtle differences between the two verbs to communicate effectively and avoid confusion.

Theory:

ğŸ”¹ "Must" is used to express necessity or obligation.

ğŸ”¹ "Canâ€™t" is used to express impossibility or inability.

ğŸ”¹ "Canâ€™t" can be used to express a lack of ability or resources.

TOPIC: Expressing possibility with "may" and "might" 1 (Permission and likelihood)
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“š Theory Card: Expressing Possibility with "May" and "Might" 1 (Permission and Likelihood) ğŸ¤”

Theory:

* "May" and "might" are used to express possibility or permission.
* "May" is more formal and polite, while "might" is more informal and conversational.
* Both words can be used to express likelihood, but "may" is more likely to be used in formal situations.

Examples:

ğŸ“ May I go to the party tonight? (formal permission)
ğŸ¤” Might I go to the party tonight? (informal permission)
ğŸ“ She may have forgotten her phone at home. (likelihood)
ğŸ¤” He might have forgotten his phone at home. (likelihood)

Remember, "may" and "might" can also be used to express possibility in the past tense, using "might have" instead of "may have".

ğŸ“ I might have forgotten my phone at home. (past possibility)
ğŸ¤” She may have forgotten her phone at home. (past possibility)

Now that you know the theory, try to use "may" and "might" in your own sentences! ğŸ’¡

TOPIC: Expressing possibility with "may" and "might" 2 (More examples and uses)
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“š Theory Card: Expressing Possibility with "May" and "Might" 2 (More Examples and Uses) ğŸ“š

Theory:

* "May" and "might" are used to express possibility or uncertainty in the future.
* Both words can be used in the sentence structure, but "may" is more formal and "might" is more informal.
* "May" is used to express a more likely possibility, while "might" is used to express a less likely possibility.
* Both words can be used in the present and past tenses, but "may" is more commonly used in the present tense, while "might" is more commonly used in the past tense.

Examples:

ğŸ“ May:

* I may go to the store later. (more likely possibility)
* She may not be able to attend the meeting. (more likely uncertainty)
* They may have already left. (more likely possibility)

ğŸ“ Might:

* I may not be able to attend the party tonight. (less likely possibility)
* She might not finish her project on time. (less likely uncertainty)
* They might have already eaten. (less likely possibility)

ğŸ“ Comparing the two:

* I may go to the store later, but I might not have time. (comparing two less likely possibilities)
* She may not be able to attend the meeting, but she might have a good reason. (comparing two more likely uncertainties)

ğŸ“ Using "may" and "might" in different contexts:

* I may be able to help you with your homework, but I might not have the time. (combining possibility and time)
* She may not be able to sing well, but she might have a beautiful voice. (combining possibility and talent)

ğŸ“ Using "may" and "might" in negative sentences:

* I may not be able to attend the party tonight, but I might have a good reason. (negative sentence with "may")
* She might not finish her project on time, but she may have a good excuse. (negative sentence with "might")

ğŸ“ Using "may" and "might" in questions:

* May I go to the store later? (formal question)
* Might I be able to help you with your homework? (informal question)

ğŸ“ Using "may" and "might" in conditional sentences:

* If I have time, I may go to the store later. (conditional sentence with "may")
* If she has a good reason, she might not be able to attend the meeting. (conditional sentence with "might")

ğŸ”¹ "Must" is used to express strong necessity or requirement in present and future situations.

ğŸ”¹ "Have to" is often used to express a personal preference or a suggestion, while "must" is used to express a strict requirement or obligation.

TOPIC: "would" in hypotheticals, politeness, and past habits
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“š Theory Card: Would in Hypotheticals, Politeness, and Past Habits ğŸ“š

Theory:

ğŸ”¹ Would is used to express hypothetical situations and their consequences.

ğŸ”¹ It can also convey politeness and indirectness in requests or offers.

ğŸ”¹ In the past tense, would is used to describe past habits or routines.

Examples:

ğŸ”¹ Hypothetical Situations:

If I won the lottery, I would buy a house on the beach. (expressing a hypothetical situation and its consequence)

ğŸ”¹ Politeness:

ğŸ”¹ Past Habits:

I would always go to the gym on Saturdays. (describing a past habit)

I would never eat dessert before dinner. (describing a past habit in a negative context)

ğŸ”¹ Exceptions:

ğŸ”¸ Would not is used to express refusal or denial.

I would not eat that, it looks disgusting. (expressing refusal)

ğŸ”¹ Would can also be used in conditional sentences to express hypothetical situations and their consequences.

TOPIC: Making requests, offers, and asking for permission with modal verbs
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“ Theory Card: Modal Verbs for Making Requests, Offers, and Asking for Permission ğŸ“

Theory:

Modal verbs are used to express degrees of necessity, possibility, and obligation in requests, offers, and asking for permission. They can also convey politeness and soften the tone of a request.

Here are the main modal verbs used for making requests, offers, and asking for permission:

ğŸ”µ Can: to express ability or capacity to do something.

Example: "Can you pass the salt?"

ğŸ”· Could: to express possibility or ability in the past.

Example: "Could you please pass the salt?"

ğŸ”¹ May: to express permission or possibility.

Example: "May I have the salt, please?"

ğŸ”º Must: to express necessity or obligation.

Example: "You must pass the salt."

ğŸ”» Shall: to express future action or certainty.

Example: "Shall I pass the salt?"

ğŸ”¼ Will: to express future action or intention.

Example: "Will you pass the salt?"

Examples:

ğŸ“ Requesting something:

* "Can you pass the salt?" (expressing ability)
* "Could you please pass the salt?" (expressing possibility)
* "May I have the salt, please?" (expressing permission)
* "You must pass the salt." (expressing necessity)
* "Shall I pass the salt?" (expressing future action or certainty)
* "Will you pass the salt?" (expressing future action or intention)

ğŸ“ Making an offer:

* "I can help you with that." (expressing ability)
* "I could help you with that." (expressing possibility)
* "I may be able to help you with that." (expressing permission)
* "I must help you with that." (expressing necessity)
* "I shall help you with that." (expressing future action or certainty)
* "I will help you with that." (expressing future action or intention)

ğŸ“ Asking for permission:

* "May I go to the bathroom?" (expressing permission)
* "Can I go to the bathroom?" (expressing ability)
* "Could I go to the bathroom?" (expressing possibility)
* "Must I go to the bathroom?" (expressing necessity)
* "Shall I go to the bathroom?" (expressing future action or certainty)
* "Will I be able to go to the bathroom?" (expressing future action or intention)

Remember, modal verbs can be used in different ways depending on the context and the speaker's intention. It's important to practice using them in different situations to become more comfortable and confident with their usage.

TOPIC: Basic Passive Constructions (is done / was done)
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“š Theory Card: Basic Passive Constructions (is done / was done) ğŸ“

Theory:

* Basic passive constructions involve transforming an active sentence into a passive one by using the verb "to be" + the past participle of the main verb.
* The subject of the active sentence becomes the object of the passive sentence, and the verb "to be" is used in the present or past tense.
* The past participle of the main verb agrees with the subject in number and gender.

Examples:

ğŸ”µ Active: The teacher gives the student a book.
ğŸ”´ Passive: The student is given a book by the teacher.

ğŸ”µ Active: The company will launch a new product next month.
ğŸ”´ Passive: The new product will be launched by the company next month.

ğŸ”´ Passive: The man was bitten by the dog.

TOPIC: Advanced Passive Constructions (be done / been done / being done)
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“š Theory Card: Advanced Passive Constructions (be done / been done / being done) ğŸ”

Theory:

* Advanced passive constructions involve using the passive voice to express complex actions or states that have been completed, are ongoing, or have been happening continuously.
* The passive voice is used to focus on the action or state, rather than the person or thing performing the action.
* There are three main types of advanced passive constructions:
	+ Be done: The action or state is completed and has a specific time reference.
	+ Been done: The action or state is completed and has no specific time reference.
	+ Being done: The action or state is ongoing and has no specific time reference.

Examples:

ğŸ” Be done:

* The project has been done by the team. (specific time reference)
* The research has been completed. (specific time reference)

ğŸ” Been done:

* The company has been sold. (no specific time reference)
* The city has been renovated. (no specific time reference)

ğŸ” Being done:

* The meeting is being done online. (ongoing and no specific time reference)
* The project is being worked on. (ongoing and no specific time reference)

Remember, the passive voice can be used to create more formal or impersonal writing, and it can also be used to emphasize the action or state rather than the person or thing performing it.

TOPIC: Varieties of Passive (Multiple forms and uses)
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“š Theory Card: Varieties of Passive (Multiple forms and uses) ğŸ“š

Theory:

ğŸ”¹ Passive voice is a grammatical construction in which the subject of the sentence is acted upon by the verb, rather than performing the action described by the verb.

ğŸ”¹ There are several forms of passive voice, including:

ğŸ”º Simple passive: The subject is acted upon by the verb, and the verb is in the passive form (e.g. "The ball was thrown by John").

ğŸ”» Transitive passive: The subject is acted upon by the verb, and the verb is in the passive form (e.g. "The ball was thrown").

ğŸ”¼ Intransitive passive: The subject is acted upon by the verb, and the verb is in the passive form (e.g. "The ball was thrown").

ğŸ”½ Phrasal passive: A combination of a verb and a preposition or an adverb that creates a passive meaning (e.g. "The ball was kicked out of the field").

Examples:

ğŸ”¹ Simple passive:

* The ball was thrown by John.
* The book was written by Jane.

ğŸ”» Transitive passive:

* The ball was thrown.
* The ball was kicked.

ğŸ”¼ Intransitive passive:

* The ball was thrown.
* The ball was kicked.

ğŸ”½ Phrasal passive:

* The ball was kicked out of the field.
* The ball was thrown away.

I hope this theory card helps you understand the different forms and uses of passive voice! ğŸ˜Š

TOPIC: Expressions with "it is said that", "he is supposed to" (Impersonal passive structures)
THEORY_CARD:
Theory Card: Impersonal Passive Structures with "it is said that" and "he is supposed to"

Theory:
Impersonal passive structures are used to describe a situation or event without specifying who is performing the action. These structures are formed using "it is said that" or "he is supposed to" followed by a verb in the passive voice.

Examples:

ğŸ”µ It is said that the new policy will be implemented next month. (The action is the implementation of the policy, but it is not specified who will perform the action.)

ğŸ”µ He is supposed to finish the project by the end of the week. (The action is the finishing of the project, but it is not specified who will perform the action.)

ğŸ”µ It is said that the company will launch a new product next year. (The action is the launching of the product, but it is not specified who will perform the action.)

ğŸ”µ He is supposed to attend the meeting tomorrow. (The action is the attending of the meeting, but it is not specified who will perform the action.)

Note: Impersonal passive structures can also be used to describe a situation or event that is not certain or expected, as in the following examples:

ğŸ”µ It is said that the company might launch a new product next year. (The action is the launching of the product, but it is not certain or expected.)

ğŸ”µ He is supposed to finish the project by the end of the week, but it's not sure if he will be able to. (The action is the finishing of the project, but it is not certain or expected.)

TOPIC: Causative Form "have something done" (Arranging for services or actions by others)
THEORY_CARD:
ğŸ“ Theory Card: Causative Form "have something done" (Arranging for services or actions by others)

Theory:

ğŸ”¹ The causative form "have something done" is used to describe the act of arranging for someone to perform a service or action on your behalf.

ğŸ”¹ This structure is commonly used when you want to request that someone performs an action for you, but you don't want to do it yourself.

ğŸ”¹ The subject of the sentence is the person who is requesting the service, and the object is the person or thing that is being acted upon.

Examples:

ğŸ”¹ Can you have my car washed? (Requesting that someone wash your car)

ğŸ”¹ I have my hair cut every week. (Arranging for someone to cut your hair)

ğŸ”¹ The hotel had our room cleaned daily. (Requesting that the hotel clean your room)

ğŸ”¹ The company had the project done by a professional team. (Arranging for a professional team to complete a project)

ğŸ”¹ The teacher had the students take a quiz. (Requesting that the students take a quiz)

ğŸ”¹ The client had the report written by a professional writer. (Arranging for a professional writer to write a report)

ğŸ”¹ The manager had the employee trained on the new software. (Requesting that the employee be trained on new software)

ğŸ”¹ The company had the equipment maintained by a professional technician. (Arranging for a professional technician to maintain equipment)
